messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Chicago Shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Hi all, Just thought I would get the word out early on this. Gordon MIDWEST TOKEN KAI  INC. is pleased to announce CHICAGO 2007 *SHINSA* By the NTHK from Japan
messages.messageBody:
Hi all,



Just thought I would get the word out early on this.



Gordon



MIDWEST TOKEN KAI INC.



is pleased to announce



CHICAGO 2007

*SHINSA*

By the NTHK from Japan

and

Sword show

90+ Tables (Last year sold out)

April 27-28-29

Sheraton Chicago Northwest: Arlington Heights Illinois

New dates: Beginning of Japans Golden Week, with a special invitation to
Japanese collectors and dealers



For information contact: Marc Porpora

Phone: 847-945-2627 or e-mail: ichimonji7@...



Look for new web site, to come (under construction) midwesttokenkai.com





[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Re: Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Brian, Thanks, nice photos, and welcome.  It seems like this style of yasurime is most common on copper and copper alloy (shakudo) habaki.  I ve seen it
messages.messageBody:
Brian,
Thanks, nice photos, and welcome. It seems like this style of yasurime is most common on copper and copper alloy (shakudo) habaki. I've seen it occasionally in silver, but I don't recall seeing it on gold habaki.

Any other observations about smooth sided habaki with filework on the edges?

Jim



Greetings all, from a new member.
Since the topic is "cat-scratch" designs, I thought I would post a pic
of the habaki on my new acquisition.
As you can see, the large areas of the habaki on this one are smooth,
with the "cat scratch" designs only on the sides.

Just thought it might be interesting.

http://www.icon.co.za/~goth/Wakizashi/Habaki.jpg

Regards,
Brian



[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]

-----Oorspronkelijk bericht-----
Van: Barry Thomas [mailto:warlord@...]
Verzonden: zaterdag 17 januari 2004 13:51
Aan: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Onderwerp: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and
kogai ura


Barry Thomas wrote:
>> Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always
>> end in a "burr" which is hammered flat and forms
>> part of the decoration.

and Peter Bleed replied:
> Forgive a technical note. I happen to have seen
> Hagawa-san making "cat scratches"...
> ...the marks are made with a special tool...

I have never thought much about the techniques of making habaki (having
simply
admired great work), so this is an interesting observation of Peter's.
This
would make a habaki where the whole surface is covered with short
excusions
ending in a "burr" - like some cruder WW2 gunto habaki I have seen, but
the
"burrs" are plainly put in individually rather than with a
multiple-toothed
tool. However, I'm sure there are many different techniques for making
the
nekogaki/amegaki. I had in mind those where the "burr" clearly occurs
at the
end of a longer excursion or cut made (I guess) with a burin-like
instrument,
hence the "burrs" are rather sparse in number compared to the technique
Pete
described. Interestingly, the solid silver habaki on Showa period
Gassan swords
has a pattern of "burrs" in a repeated square arrangement. I could put
up an
image if any one wants to see it.

Barry Thomas.



_____

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: ... I have never thought much about the techniques of making habaki (having simply admired great work), so this is an interesting observation of Peter s.  This
messages.messageBody:
Barry Thomas wrote:
>> Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always
>> end in a "burr" which is hammered flat and forms
>> part of the decoration.

and Peter Bleed replied:
> Forgive a technical note. I happen to have seen
> Hagawa-san making "cat scratches"...
> ...the marks are made with a special tool...

I have never thought much about the techniques of making habaki (having simply
admired great work), so this is an interesting observation of Peter's. This
would make a habaki where the whole surface is covered with short excusions
ending in a "burr" - like some cruder WW2 gunto habaki I have seen, but the
"burrs" are plainly put in individually rather than with a multiple-toothed
tool. However, I'm sure there are many different techniques for making the
nekogaki/amegaki. I had in mind those where the "burr" clearly occurs at the
end of a longer excursion or cut made (I guess) with a burin-like instrument,
hence the "burrs" are rather sparse in number compared to the technique Pete
described. Interestingly, the solid silver habaki on Showa period Gassan swords
has a pattern of "burrs" in a repeated square arrangement. I could put up an
image if any one wants to see it.

Barry Thomas.

Probably the first word is dogu, got me on the second one.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chicago Shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Gordon, there is a Japanese expression I cannot remember correctly ( I can remember the function of the expression ) which was something like dogi wola ( I
messages.messageBody:
Gordon, there is a Japanese expression I cannot remember correctly ( I can remember the function of the expression ) which was something like dogi wola ( I know that is spelt wrong, Tom, help me out here ) who's job it was to carry around all the dirty dogi for the Karate-ka and wash them for the seniors. You need an equivalent here to carry all your swords for you. A porter of sorts, one of course that can be trusted.

Rich


----- Original Message -----
From: Gordon Robson
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Saturday, January 17, 2004 8:53 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chicago Shinsa


Depends on the condition of my arm. The first time I brought 19 and
killed myself. Last year it was 10. That seems manageable for my whimpy
body. Also, as you note, Yamato are few and far between. We will try to
have Oei period pieces and maybe even an Nambokucho piece. I know of a
Ko-Senjuin that is signed, but I don't know if we can borrow it. After
Oei, then we have a lot of stuff available. Anyway, we will try to have
at least one or two examples from the five classic schools.

Gordon

On 2004.1.16, at 03:21 PM, samurai@... wrote:

> <robsongo@...> writes:
>
> > Hi gang, I have an update on the Chicago shinsa. We have had to
> change
> > the date due to schedule conflicts for Hagihara sensei. The new dates
> > are 17-19 September. I hope this doesn't rain on anyone's parade. It
> > also looks like this year's traveling sword show theme will be
> Yamato.
>
> Ooooo. Most excellent with the Yamato. It seems to be much harder to be
> able to see a spectrum of Yamato swords than anything else.
>
> How many do you plan on bringing?
>
> - darcy
>

messages.msgSnippet: The contact person, is, as always with the Chicago show, Bob Coleman. I do not know the hotel yet. The reservation was just made yesterday. I expect Bob will
messages.messageBody:
The contact person, is, as always with the Chicago show, Bob Coleman. I
do not know the hotel yet. The reservation was just made yesterday. I
expect Bob will be putting out the word very soon.

Gordon

messages.subject: Re: Chicago Shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: ... date ... -19 ... looks ... Gordon - Do you have details of where, etc. Hotels, contact persons, etc. Rich S
messages.messageBody:
--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, Gordon Robson <robsongo@s...>
wrote:
> Hi gang,
>
> I have an update on the Chicago shinsa. We have had to change the
date
> due to schedule conflicts for Hagihara sensei. The new dates are 17
-19
> September. I hope this doesn't rain on anyone's parade. It also
looks
> like this year's traveling sword show theme will be Yamato.
>
> Gordon

Gordon -

Do you have details of where, etc. Hotels, contact
persons, etc.

Rich S

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chicago Shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: ... Ooooo. Most excellent with the Yamato. It seems to be much harder to be able to see a spectrum of Yamato swords than anything else. How many do you plan on
messages.messageBody:
<robsongo@...> writes:

> Hi gang, I have an update on the Chicago shinsa. We have had to change
> the date due to schedule conflicts for Hagihara sensei. The new dates
> are 17-19 September. I hope this doesn't rain on anyone's parade. It
> also looks like this year's traveling sword show theme will be Yamato.

Ooooo. Most excellent with the Yamato. It seems to be much harder to be
able to see a spectrum of Yamato swords than anything else.

How many do you plan on bringing?

- darcy

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Chicago Shinsa
messages.msgSnippet: Hi gang, I have an update on the Chicago shinsa. We have had to change the date due to schedule conflicts for Hagihara sensei. The new dates are 17-19
messages.messageBody:
Hi gang,

I have an update on the Chicago shinsa. We have had to change the date
due to schedule conflicts for Hagihara sensei. The new dates are 17-19
September. I hope this doesn't rain on anyone's parade. It also looks
like this year's traveling sword show theme will be Yamato.

Gordon

messages.subject: RE: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Rich mate isn t this the same as on the lower parts of the habaki illustrated by the Kashima Sisters? Btw your pic seems to show the burr that Barry was
messages.messageBody:
Rich mate isn't this the same as on the lower parts of the habaki
illustrated by the Kashima Sisters?

Btw your pic seems to show the 'burr' that Barry was talking about quite
well if I understand it correctly.

- Matt

scratches on gold and not shakudo?? I can only think that shakudo is

subdued, whereas gold is "hade" - flashy - and needs to be subdued,
the

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Peter, Barry, Jim...what a fascinating discussion here! What a treat that must be to have the opportunity to sit down and watch a master craftsman create such
messages.messageBody:
Peter, Barry, Jim...what a fascinating discussion here! What a treat that must be to have the opportunity to sit down and watch a master craftsman create such artwork!

Ron
STL
----- Original Message -----
From: Peter A Bleed
To: nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com
Sent: Thursday, January 15, 2004 8:10 AM
Subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura








Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always end in a "burr" which is
hammered flat and forms part of the decoration.

Barry Thomas.

Forgive a technical note. I happen to have seen Hagawa-san making "cat
scratches" (sorry, I can't recall what he called them). I have seen him do
both gold and silver. I think in both cases, the marks are made with a
special tool. It has a series of about 6 sharp teeth on a blade that is
curved upward. The tool is pushed on to the surface to be finished in a
rocking motion. This is why the marked are denser on one side. Obviously,
seeing this done is pure ballet, but it goes extremely fast, like 30
seconds to a habaki. The "burr" that Barry mentions is done by burnishing
the surface after it has been scratched. In the case of gold, the
burnishing tool is itself gold with a carefully maintained rough finish. It
had to be cleaned (degreased?) before it was used, but it only took a
couple of stokes to finish the surface. After that the tools went back to
its neat little saya!
Peter Bleed

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always end in a burr which is hammered flat and forms part of the decoration. Barry Thomas. Forgive a technical
messages.messageBody:
Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always end in a "burr" which is
hammered flat and forms part of the decoration.

Barry Thomas.

Forgive a technical note. I happen to have seen Hagawa-san making "cat
scratches" (sorry, I can't recall what he called them). I have seen him do
both gold and silver. I think in both cases, the marks are made with a
special tool. It has a series of about 6 sharp teeth on a blade that is
curved upward. The tool is pushed on to the surface to be finished in a
rocking motion. This is why the marked are denser on one side. Obviously,
seeing this done is pure ballet, but it goes extremely fast, like 30
seconds to a habaki. The "burr" that Barry mentions is done by burnishing
the surface after it has been scratched. In the case of gold, the
burnishing tool is itself gold with a carefully maintained rough finish. It
had to be cleaned (degreased?) before it was used, but it only took a
couple of stokes to finish the surface. After that the tools went back to
its neat little saya!
Peter Bleed

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Jim and all (a memorable phrase) ... Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always end in a burr which is hammered flat and forms part of the decoration.
messages.messageBody:
Jim and all (a memorable phrase)

> Nekkogaki yasurimei, "irregular scratches as if done
> by a cat," is one of them. I don't think that it's meant
> to refer to the uniform file finish that's seen on Goto
> pieces and others, although it does get misused that
> way in the West.
>...
> If it did represent rain and this was somehow important
> to accompany the shishi, karasu, dragon, etc., they why
> didn't it also appear on the shakudo versions of these motifs?

Note that the scratches on habaki nearly always end in a "burr" which is
hammered flat and forms part of the decoration. Only rarely is the chisel cut
clean. One can imagine a cat scratching a tree (or you!!) and leaving a curled
bit of bark (or flesh!) at the end of the scratch. Hence nekogaki. In the case
of the Goto gold kozuka finish, or those kozuka finished without the "burr" at
the end of the scratch, then "rain" is most likely a correct descriptor. Why
scratches on gold and not shakudo?? I can only think that shakudo is "shibui" -
subdued, whereas gold is "hade" - flashy - and needs to be subdued, the
scratches doing this to a "T".

Barry Thomas.

messages.subject: Re: [nihontostudy] Ko-Kat scratches - yasurimei on kozuka and kogai ura
messages.msgSnippet: Pages 179 and 180 of Kajihara s glossary have terms for a variety of these decorative finishes.  Nekkogaki yasurimei, irregular scratches as if done by a
messages.messageBody:
Pages 179 and 180 of Kajihara's glossary have terms for a variety of these decorative finishes. Nekkogaki yasurimei, "irregular scratches as if done by a cat," is one of them. I don't think that it's meant to refer to the uniform file finish that's seen on Goto pieces and others, although it does get misused that way in the West.

There are definitely Edo period machibori kozuka with falling rain pattern yasurimei. It's not so densely done and does look like ukiyo-e shigure (drizzle). I suppose that the sujikai yasuri on Goto pieces could depict a downpour... but probably not.

Given the aesthetics of early Goto pieces, I don't think that it was intended as a representational element. Think of how austere their presentations are. If it did represent rain and this was somehow important to accompany the shishi, karasu, dragon, etc., they why didn't it also appear on the shakudo versions of these motifs?
Jim



I never did understand the "cat scratches" idea whereas "falling rain" seems right in keeping with things Japanese. Suspect some 19th century European came up with blaming the cat.

Ron
STL

[Non-text portions of this message have been removed]
